notes.text:
An update for dnsmasq is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The dnsmasq packages contain dnsmasq, a lightweight DNS (Domain Name Server) forwarder and DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) server.

Security Fixes:

* dnsmasq: Heap use after free in dhcp6_no_relay (CVE-2022-0934)

* dnsmasq: default maximum EDNS.0 UDP packet size was set to 4096 but should be 1232 (CVE-2023-28450)

* dnsmasq: bind9: KeyTrap - Extreme CPU consumption in DNSSEC validator (CVE-2023-50387)

* dnsmasq: bind9: Preparing an NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU resources (CVE-2023-50868)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

acknowledgments.summary: This issue was discovered by Red Hat.

notes.text: A single-byte, non-arbitrary write/use-after-free flaw was found in dnsmasq. This flaw allows an attacker who sends a crafted packet processed by dnsmasq, potentially causing a denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: dnsmasq: Heap use after free in dhcp6_no_relay
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The severity of this flaw was set to Moderate because this is a 1-byte out-of-bounds write/use-after-free issue where the attacker does not control the data written (it is predefined in a header file). The highest impact is only to availability.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: dnsmasq: Heap use after free in dhcp6_no_relay

cwe.name: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

notes.text: A flaw was found in Dnsmasq. The default maximum EDNS.0 UDP packet size was set to 4096 but should be 1232 because of DNS Flag Day 2020.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: dnsmasq: default maximum EDNS.0 UDP packet size was set to 4096 but should be 1232
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: dnsmasq: default maximum EDNS.0 UDP packet size was set to 4096 but should be 1232

notes.text:
Processing specially crafted responses coming from DNSSEC-signed zones can lead to uncontrolled CPU usage, leading to a Denial of Service in the DNSSEC-validating resolver side.

This vulnerability applies only for systems where DNSSEC validation is enabled.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: bind9: KeyTrap - Extreme CPU consumption in DNSSEC validator
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
There are no mitigations for this issue that meet Red Hat's secure workaround criteria. Updating the package to the version containing the fix is recommended.

vulnerabilities.title: bind9: KeyTrap - Extreme CPU consumption in DNSSEC validator

notes.text:
A flaw was found in bind9. By flooding a DNSSEC resolver with responses coming from a DNSEC-signed zone using NSEC3, an attacker can lead the targeted resolver to a CPU exhaustion, further leading to a Denial of Service on the targeted host.

This vulnerability applies only for systems where DNSSEC validation is enabled.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: bind9: Preparing an NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU resources
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
There are no mitigations for this issue that meet Red Hat's secure workaround criteria. Updating the package to the version containing the fix is recommended.

vulnerabilities.title: bind9: Preparing an NSEC3 closest encloser proof can exhaust CPU resources
